content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take three pictures of lower and higher plants in the same shot.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Why is it important for there to be higher and lower plants in nature?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Research the characteristics of lower and higher plants. Identify how they are the same and how they are different. Which type of plant, higher or lower, are you more familiar with?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take three pictures of lower plants that you can find nearby.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: If all lower plants ceased to exist, what would the impact of that be on the ecosystem? Type the top three reasons why lower plants are essential to their ecosystem. Then, put them in order, #1 being the most important reason.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following plants

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: For extra credit: Get one of these plants and maintain it, taking weekly progress pictures!

content.text: Determine three functions that a lower plant can serve, which higher plants cannot. Why is this important? Additionally, research some lower plants that you could grow yourself and identify the effect this could have on the environment around you.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw a picture depicting the stages of the plant development cycle. Take a photo of your drawing!

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What conditions are needed for germination of a seed? How difficult are these  conditions to produce?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the following detailed stages of plant development in order:

content.text: A seed in moist soil starts to germinate.
The seed begins to open and roots appear.
The roots embed themselves into the soil.
The nutrients already in the seed run out.
The plant starts to receive water and nutrients from the soil.
1-2 thin leaves form on the stem.
Flowers and/or fruit begins to appear
Seeds are developed on the flower/fruit.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Imagine a condition that would keep the plant from developing. What could this condition be, and when would it impact the plant the most in the cycle?

lessons.title: 4. Why Does a Plant Need Flowers?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find a flower outside and take a picture of it. List the parts of the flower you can see. Can you see the corolla petals, stamens, sepals, and pistils? Describe where each of these parts are.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe in a couple sentences what the interaction is between plants and flowers in nature.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order the parts of the flower from the outermost part of the flower to the innermost part.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the following parts of the flower to its function.

options.name: Sepals
options.title: Protect the inner parts of the flower

options.name: Pistil
options.title: Where a fruit is developed and seeds are formed

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Flowers grow on plants, but there are some plants that don’t have flowers. Identify 3 plants that do have flowers, and 3 that do not have flowers. How are these two groups different from each other? Lastly, research something a flower provides for a plant and summarize it here.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find a seed, split it open and take a picture. Describe what you see.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Provide a definition of a seed. What is its purpose in creating life?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order the steps for the process of pollination from beginning to end.

content.text: A pollinator (like a bee), collects nectar from a flower.
The pollinator rubs up against pollen from the stamens of the flower and it sticks to the pollinator’s body.
The pollinator goes to another flower, carrying the pollen.
The pollinator reaches a flower and deposits its pollen on the stigma of the flower.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What do you think would happen if there were less pollinators, such as bees?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Research ways that you can support pollination or bees. List your top 3 favorite methods that you found and describe how easy or hard you think these would be to replicate. Find one to do over the next week (or longer) and take pictures!

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Choose a plant of your choice and plant a seed.  Take progress pictures over the course of one week.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What happens during the germination of a plant? Describe the process that occurs.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: List 3 plants and its purpose. Do you think a lot of people around you use plants for purposes like these? Why or why not?

content.text: Think about the plant you planted earlier.  Think about or research other plants that you could plant that could provide a clear purpose. Purposes could be that they provide food, habitats for animals, provide resources for pollinators and more.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: There are many different ways that seeds can be distributed and planted. Draw one of these ways and take a picture of your drawing.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe one way in which new, wild plants emerge.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the following method of seed dispersal to the kind of seed

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: How long would it take to change this area?

content.text: Find an area nearby that has greenery and plants. Observe the area, how do you think the plants got there? Find an area that you think that could use more plants. Take a picture of that area and develop a plan for how you would improve it using the following questions as a guide.
How would adding plants here help?
Who would maintain it? Would it need maintenance?

lessons.title: 8. How to protect plants from extinction

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take an updated picture of the plant you planted in Lesson 6 to show progress.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What do you think would happen in 1 year, 10 years, and 100 years if plants ceased to exist?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Research plants in Kazakhstan that are at a risk of extinction. List them and put them in order, #1 being the plant facing the highest risk of extinction currently.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following plants into the categories of at risk of extinction or not-at-risk:

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Spend 15 mins researching how you can help plants at a risk for extinction. Pick your favorite method that you find and write a pitch that you would use to try to get someone to support this effort. Record a video with an adult in your life where you give them the pitch!

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Go outside and look around for a symbiotic relationship. Take a picture of this relationship, or take a picture of each member of the relationship separately.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Why is the process of symbiosis important in the animal, marine life, and insect ecosystem?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: An example of a mutualistic relationship is between an anemone and a clownfish. Anemones are incredibly vulnerable to environmental changes due to climate change. These changes cause bleaching of the anemones. Their internal food supply is lost and these conditions can lead to their death. Hypothesize what you think would happen to the clownfish if there was loss of a lot of anemone due to bleaching. If you’re not sure, conduct some outside research.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Using the above chart, multiply the amount of servings you have of each food per year by the CO2 emissions. This is the carbon footprint for that food. Do this for each food, and add up your total. Conduct some research on what this total means, what is this amount of carbon emissions equal to? Does this surprise you? Analyze your results.

content.text: While animals have many complex relationships with one another, they also have relationships with humans. Realistically, a lot of our relationships with wild animals are in the form of food. Did you know that the food you consume can contribute to your carbon footprint? Your carbon footprint is the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of your actions.

The food you eat matters! Let’s calculate an estimate of your carbon footprint due to food consumption for a few common foods. Estimate how many servings you have of each of the above foods in one year.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: One example of an insect is a butterfly. They have clearly visible stages of development. Look outside for an example of one of these stages of development, whether it be as an egg, caterpillar, in a chrysalis, or a butterfly and take a picture. If you can’t find any examples, draw one and identify what stage of development the image depicts.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe the insect development process from birth to maturity. Identify each stage and expand on each.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order the following stages of development of insects.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Choose one of these categories and do some research on examples, what they provide for the environment, and how humans could use them more effectively. Summarize your answer to these questions here!

content.text: Insects can help the environment in many different ways and are very important to it. There are three main categories of insects that can be used to help the environment. These are pollinators, predators, and parasitizers.

lessons.title: 3. Why do Animals Eat Different Foods?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find and take a picture of an animal nearby. Then, find and take a picture of a source of food for this animal.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe the different categories of animals based on the foods they eat. Why is it important that different animals have different sources of food?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following foods into being part of a carnivore or herbivore diet:

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Find reliable sources that explain how a meat diet, versus a plant-based diet, impacts the environment. What are the pros and cons of each? Summarize your findings here. (Hint: Look into greenhouse gas emissions, water use, carbon footprint, etc.)

content.text: We can identify and research the diets of our favorite animals, but humans as a species are different from animals as many of us have very different diets from each other. Some people eat meat, some are vegetarians, pescatarians, or vegans. There are studies that show that meat consumption contributes to a large amount of greenhouse gas emissions. Do your own research on this topic.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find a plant or animal and take a picture of it. Then, find a source of energy for the plant or animal you chose and upload a picture of that as well.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Identify the various sources of energy for animals and the sources of energy for plants and describe each source.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the steps of the energy transfer process in the correct order.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: After entering your meal plan, answer the following questions? How different would this diet be from your current one? How difficult do you think it would be? Would this have a positive or negative impact on the environment? For extra points, actually follow your meal plan for one day and upload pictures of each meal!

content.text: As humans, it is really important that we get enough energy from the food that we eat. Think back to the last lesson where you researched meat versus plant based diets. Pick either a vegetarian, pescatarian, or vegan diet to look into more closely. You may have to do some more research to identify what exactly each diet means. After doing some research, make a meal plan for one day that fits the diet you chose. Make a plan for what you would eat for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Think back to the snapshot exercise you did in the last lesson. You were asked to capture an image of a plant or animal and its source of energy. Now, take a picture of the next link that would come in the food chain. For example, if last lesson you took a picture of grass, and its source of energy (the sun), I could now take a picture of a rabbit because it would eat the grass.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe what a food chain is and how the structure of the food chain in any given ecosystem looks.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: The hierarchy of the food chain generally follows the order of primary producers, to primary consumers, to secondary consumers, to tertiary consumers. Put the following animals in order according to this hierarchy.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Where do you think most of your food comes from? What are the practices used? These practices can apply to many things, such as treatment of the animals, methods of growing food, who grows and takes care of the food, etc. Analyze these practices. What could be improved?

content.text: The food chains of animals show us a clear delineation of how they get their food. The chain from which we get our food as humans can get a little more complicated, and may even be a mystery to many.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of an animal native to your area. If you can’t find it, draw a picture and upload that.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What animal is native to your area or an area near you? How are the population levels of this animal?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Animals adapt to their environment and have specific features due to the area they are native to. Pick an animal and do some research on their environment. What features and adaptations do they have that are necessary for this environment?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the following animals to the area closest to where they originate.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Many animals adapt to their environment in order to compete better for limited resources such as food. As humans, some of us have a very easy time at finding food, but many don’t. It is important to not waste food as that is wasting an incredibly valuable resource. This week, compete with your classmates to see which household can waste the least amount of food.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture off the internet of an endangered animal native to your country and upload it.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Do you think many people know what animals are endangered? How could you increase awareness of this issue?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort this collection of animals to either of the three categories.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Now research all ten individually and write what is causing them to become extinct in reality. Which did you get right and what were the differences?

content.text: Compile a list of the top ten most endangered animals native to the country. Without researching, write one sentence next to each animal talking about why you think each animal is endangered.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find and upload a picture of an animal that was once endangered but it is not anymore.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe the largest risks animals face in the world. Propose how those dangers could be addressed.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Choose one animal from the list compiled above. Strategize and write about your proposed solution to protect that animal. Consider the diet, environment, and other factors contributing to the extinction of that animal.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw a diagram of the human excretory system that includes the most important organs for the system. Label each of these organs and upload a photo.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is the excretory system? What natural processes does it include?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the following excretory organs involved in the passage of urine in order, starting from where the urine begins.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: There are many different systems within our own bodies, making them incredibly complex. While these are amazing systems, sometimes things can go wrong. Whether these complications result in a very treatable illness, or more serious diseases, the access we all have to resources that will improve our health are varied. The United Nations has 17 Sustainable Development Goals, which you may have heard of. Do some research on SDG #3 Good Health and Well-Being. They mention several diseases and afflictions they are aiming to affect. Pick one of these to study for the next few lessons. To start, write a paragraph of what you find about the option you chose with a quick google search. Write down 3 questions you already have.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw a simple diagram of the human nervous system and upload a photo.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is the human nervous system? What are some features and examples of what it does?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Correctly order the steps of the human nervous system from input of stimulus to reaction.

content.text: Signals from the external environment come in through the nerves.
The signal is transported to the spinal cord.
The signal is transported to the brain.
The information is transmitted back to the spinal cord.
The nerves carry the information to the organ it applies to.
The organ executes the proper reaction.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following situations into their category.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: What would you do to improve their approach?

content.text: Think back to the disease you chose to study last lesson. In this lesson, research some of the organizations that are trying to help this problem. Make a slideshow that answers the following questions for at least two organizations:
What is the name of the organization?
What progress have they made so far?
How would you rate their approach if you had to give them a grade?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of something that would cause a stimulus if touched. Take a second picture of the reaction you would have if you did touch it.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe what would happen if the nervous system failed in one’s body. What implications would this have?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: What is preventing certain groups of people  from this course of action? Upon reflecting, create a poster identifying one thing preventing treatment for some people. Identify the people who would experience this, and finally come up with your proposed solution to this problem.

content.text: Last lesson you made a slideshow about organizations working to address incredibly harmful diseases. In this lesson, identify treatments or practices that are supposed to either cure or positively affect the disease or affiliations you chose to study. Pick one of these approaches and reflect on reasons why people would not be able to acquire this treatment.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Get a piece of ice, and let it sit out. Take pictures as the ice melts that depicts distinct changes.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Refer back to the photographs you took in the previous activity. Explain how the properties of the ice cube changes from each photo to the next.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Find five pure substances in your household. Identify them and then explain what makes a substance pure.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Examine three different rooms and take notes on where the dust is found and in what areas it is either better or worse. Write a summary of your findings and the differences from area to area.

content.text: Substances, like the air around us can become contaminated. Air quality is really important as poor air quality can lead to serious health problems. Indoor air quality can be impacted by the dust levels in your home. Dust can lead to breathing issues, especially for people with asthma. Take this time to look around different rooms of your home and examine them for dust.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Using substances you have in your home, make a mixture and take a photo. Is this a heterogenous or homogenous mixture?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: If you had to describe the term “substance” to someone younger than you, how would you describe it?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How do the properties of substances influence the phase changes that it can execute?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the phase change to the correct term.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: In the last lesson, you were asked to look around your home and examine the dust levels. Now, do some research on how dust particles can cause breathing problems. Then, look into some ways that you can address the problems associated with indoor air quality.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw a picture of how the behavior of molecules change when they undergo the phase change from solid to liquid to gas. Upload a photo of your drawing.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Substances can undergo a physical change or a chemical change. Explain what the difference is between the two.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following situations into whether they are an example of a physical or chemical change.

options.name: Physical change
options.title: Ripping up a piece of paper

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: When substances are mixed together, those substances either retain their original properties or they change upon interaction with each other. Air pollution is actually a mixture. Air pollution is a substance made up of many different particles. Research what the parts of this mixture are and what their properties are. Write a paragraph summary of what you found.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Create a presentation that you can give to your family addressing the following key topics: Why should you wait until a day with better air quality? How do you know it’s a bad air quality day?

content.text: Pollution in the air that leads to serious environmental consequences and health issues is a huge problem and it is difficult to know what, as individuals, we can do to help. If your lawnmower has a gasoline engine, then running it can pollute the air as much as a car. If the air quality that day is particularly bad, it is better to hold off mowing the lawn for another day.

lessons.title: 4. How Do the Properties of Substances Change?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Execute a situation where a phase change occurs and the properties of the substance do not change. Take before and after photos.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Consider the following situation: you dissolve salt in water, creating a mixture. You know that this is a physical change and therefore the salt and water each retain their original properties. How would reverse this change, separating the water from the salt in this mixture? What does this tell you about physical changes?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following indicators into the kind of change it is associated with.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Choose one of these sources to research further. Answer the following questions about your chosen source: What data supports that this is a main source of air pollution? Why is it a source of air pollution? What alternatives are there that could minimize the impact of this source?

content.text: For the past few lessons, we’ve been focusing on air quality. This is a really important topic to understand and care about. While it is important to understand what you can do to improve the situation as an individual, you must also understand who and what the greatest contributors are to air quality issues. In Kazakhstan, the largest sources of air pollution are from manufacturing, transportation, thermal power, and residential heating systems.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo where air can be seen moving things in its surroundings.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Write a definition of air. How would you describe it to a younger student?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the following steps in the order they occur as sunlight heats the ground and the air near a water reservoir.

content.text: Sunlight heats the surface of the earth.
Air close to the ground is heated.
The air becomes lighter and rises.
Cold air from nearby water moves to land.
The cold air from the water replaces the warm air.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Think back to the alternatives to the source of air pollution you found in the last lesson. Do some research to find a person or corporation who is either providing an alternative or is fighting for alternatives. Brainstorm a list of questions you have for them and write a thoughtful letter or email asking these questions.

lessons.title: 6. What Are the Benefits and Harms of the Wind?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find an area of your community that could be harmed from strong winds. Take a picture of this area and write a caption on the harm that could be caused due to wind.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Wind is caused by differences in air pressure. Wind goes from areas of high pressures to areas of low pressure. Name three possible benefits and three possible harms of these changes in air pressure that we know more commonly as wind.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following situations into whether or not they could be caused by the wind.

categories.name: Could be caused by the wind
Could not be caused by the wind

options.name: Could be caused by the wind
options.title: Erosion

options.name: Could be caused by the wind
options.title: Formation of sand dunes

options.name: Could be caused by the wind
options.title: Seed dispersal

options.name: Could not be caused by the wind
options.title: Formation of volcanoes

options.name: Could not be caused by the wind
options.title: Increased aerosol pollution in the air

options.name: Could not be caused by the wind
options.title: Decreased protection from the ozone layer

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Does Kazakhstan utilize wind turbines already? How could you improve this?

content.text: The energy that can be created by wind can be harnessed in really impactful ways. Wind energy or wind power are processes which create power and electricity through the use of wind. One way this occurs is through wind turbines.
Watch videos and do some research on how these wind turbines work. Create a presentation that answers the following questions and choose an adult to present it to.
How do wind turbines create energy?
Why are wind turbines important to have in Kazakhstan?

lessons.title: 7. What is the Importance of Air?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Identify something, whether it is a person, thing, animal, etc, in your community that needs air and upload a picture.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: If there was no longer oxygen available on Earth, what would be the instantaneous effects? What would happen after that? (Hint: What process is oxygen vital for other than for human survival?)

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: List the molecular components of air and order them according to their amounts, highest to lowest.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Use good experimental procedures and make sure your hypothesis is realistic and testable.

content.text: Let’s do an experiment! You have the opportunity to formulate your own experiment procedure and hypothesis that utilizes the sticky tape method. Cut a piece of clear tape and place it on the side of a building, leave it for 10 seconds, and then peel it off and out it onto a piece of paper. Label the date, time and location that this piece of tape is from. How many particles you get on the tape is a good indicator of air pollution in the area. But remember, the most dangerous forms of air pollution are a lot smaller than what would appear on tape.

While this is the method you will use, you can decide what exactly you are testing and your hypothesis. For example, if you want to test how air pollution changes in a day, you can conduct the experiment in the morning, noon, and night and analyze your results. Or, you could test different locations, different types of weather, are anything else you can think of! Make sure no matter what you decide to test, you conduct at least three trials!

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo in your city where air pollution is visible and upload a photo.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: In your opinion, what is the most important reason why people should care about air pollution? What are some reasons that you could give to someone who disagrees?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Air pollution in Kazakhstan specifically is due to many factors. Put the following contributors in order, starting with the largest impact.

content.text: Burning of oil and gas, which leads to soot emissions.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the activities into the correct categories.

options.name: Human Activity
options.title: Heating homes through fuels and gasses

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Below, identify where you hung the plate, upload a picture, and analyze what you see on the paper plate. What do these results tell you?

content.text: Let’s do one more experiment to help visualize the air pollution that surrounds us.
For this experiment you will need: A paper plate, Vaseline, Thread
Take the paper plate and poke a hole through it on an edge, just big enough to put the thread through so that you can hang up the plate. Rub a coating of Vaseline on one side of the plate.
Next, choose an area where you would like to test the air quality, and hang the plate there for one hour.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo of an area you can find near you that in some way influences the water cycle, participates in it, or is impacted by it.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What are the major components of the water cycle? Pick one and explain what would happen if that component was not part of the cycle.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order the following four steps of the water cycle as they would most likely occur, starting with evaporation.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: The importance of water on our Earth cannot be overestimated. Most of our water on Earth is from the ocean, which is salt water. This means, it is not drinkable. We need freshwater, which makes up only 3% of the water on earth. But, only 1% is actually available for our use. Research why only 1% of this water is available and challenges that we are facing when it comes to access to freshwater. Summarize your findings here.

lessons.title: 10. What is Precipitation and Where Is It?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find an area in your community that you think could use some precipitation. Upload a picture and identify what could happen if this area doesn’t get water soon.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Create a unique definition of precipitation that demonstrates your understanding of the term.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order the steps in the precipitation process from beginning to end.

content.text: Water vapor in the atmosphere due to evaporation combines to make bigger water droplets.
Clouds get heavier as they combine with more water droplets.
When the droplets become too heavy, the clouds release the precipitation to earth.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the form of precipitation to how it is created.

options.name: Dew
options.title: steam comes into contact with an object.

options.name: Frost
options.title: water vapor is deposited onto a surface that is colder than zero degrees celsius.

options.name: Hail
options.title: raindrops rise into highly cold areas of the atmosphere and freeze.

options.name: Sleet
options.title: snowflakes do not fully melt as they pass through a quick layer of warm air, and refreeze after passing through the warm air.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Make a guess at how much water you can save by fixing this habit, and then do some research to see what the number really is. Does the answer surprise you, why or why not?

content.text: There are things that everyone can do in order to preserve a resource as important as water. We will explore a few of those methods for preservation.
When you brush your teeth, do you let the water from the sink run as you brush? Turning the faucet off can reduce the amount of water that gets wasted everyday.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of a substance and a glass of water. Then, put the substance in the water and document using a second picture whether or not it has the ability to dissolve in water.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How would you describe solubility to a student younger than you? What experiment could you conduct to help support your explanation?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Salt (NaCl) is able to dissolve in water. Put the steps of that process in the correct order.

content.text: Water molecules pull the ions (Na and Cl) in the salt apart.
The ionic bond that holds the salt together is broken.
The sodium and chloride are surrounded by water molecules.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following substances into the correct category.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Part 2: You’ve been given two ways that you can help preserve water, but there are many more. Do some research to add on to the list of methods that can help preserve our water supply and ensure that we are using this valuable and limited resource in the most effective way possible. Pick one of these methods, which includes the two that have been presented in the past two lessons, and create an elevator pitch that tries to convince the audience on why they should utilize that method of water conservation. Try it out on a couple of friends and family members. Submit a video of it below.

content.text: Part 1: Let’s think some more about preserving water! How many days a week do you take showers? How many days a week do you take a bath? Believe it or not, showers require a significantly smaller amount of water than baths! If you take a 10 minute shower, then 25 gallons of water is used, while a bath would take 50 gallons. Calculate how much water you would save per week if you took a shower instead of a bath.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo of any water pollution in your area and upload it.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Have you seen water pollution? What was its cause and how can you reverse it? How does this pollution affect humans AND wildlife?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order the largest contributors to water pollution in Kazakhstan starting with the  highest contributor.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Many individuals want to help clean up rivers and do their part to help. Try to find a river clean up that is happening nearby and join in! If there’s not one near you, then talk to a parent and get some friends and family to join you! Go to a nearby body of water, pick up any trash that you see and dispose of it properly. The more people that join you, the better!

content.text: Pollution in water has many harmful effects, one of which is harm to wildlife in the area. Many small rivers in Kazakhstan and the area have become polluted, largely due to industrial waste.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take pictures of objects close and far away. How do your eyes differ from the lens of a Camera 📷, even though they capture a similar image?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Write about why vision and the complex processes allowing us to see are important.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the various objects into where they are transparent, translucent or opaque.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: For a week, take pictures of the sky in the morning and the evening. Make a log of what you see in the air. For example, can you see smog or pollutants? What do you suspect is there that you can’t see? Jot down observations everyday and try to find trends.

content.text: There are a lot of things in the world that we cannot see. For example, air and all of the things that may be in it. We can often see smog, which is made up of pollutants. In this instance, we can see polluted air.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a walk outside and find an object, building, anything outside, that is a darker color, like black or gray and is in direct sunlight. Take a picture and observe how your eyes feel when you look at it. Then, find something that is very light, closer to white. Take a picture and observe how your eyes feel when viewing it in direct sunlight. Compare your observations? How can you relate these results to light absorption?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Explain why some surfaces absorb more light than others. What happens to the light if it is not absorbed?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the following colors in order from absorbing the most to least amount of light.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Utilizing and understanding how light gets absorbed can be a major advantage in the energy sector. Still pretty new to the industry, solar panels are being used as an alternative to other processes that create energy which use fossil fuels. Understanding how the sun can be converted into electricity is easier if you understand how plants convert the sun into energy as well! Compare and contrast how these things are similar and different. If you need to do some research to better understand solar energy, go ahead and do that first!

lessons.title: 3. Is It Possible to Change the Shadow?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find a shadow that looks very different from what it is a shadow of. Hypothesize why it may be distorted.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe what a shadow is exactly and what elements are needed to create a shadow.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the various objects into shadow-producing and non-shadow producing.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: How can the lack of light caused by smog or the overexposure of light caused by the deterioration of the atmosphere impact wildlife and habitat? List and describe three ways.

content.text: While the shape of an object always determines the shape of its shadow, the size and shape of the shadow can change depending on the position of the light.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Grab a glass of water and a speaker. Place the speaker on high volume and hover it over the still glass of water. Photograph what you see.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe what sound reflection is and in what environments the reflection is strongest and weakest.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Order objects according to how good they are at reflecting sound. Start with the best and reflecting sound, ending at the worst of the objects provided.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Take a video where sound pollution due to construction, cars, or any other viable source is occurring. What are the negative consequences? What could be put in place to improve this situation?

content.text: Sound pollution, often present in city environments, affects the quality of life of humans and animals alike.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo of an object in your house that creates a lot of noise when in use.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How would you describe sound without using the words noise, ears, or loud?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following things that cause noise into whether or not they affect wildlife.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Pick one of these to try to do for a whole week. Write a paragraph about your current habits when it comes to the option you chose and identify how you will improve it. Everyday, provide a journal entry of your efforts and reflect on how difficult or easy this is for you to accomplish everyday. Maybe it can become a permanent change! Share your efforts with your family and try to get them to join if you can!

content.text: Noise pollution can have large negative consequences for wildlife. Environmentalists provide a few options for people to help remedy the situation. We can turn off appliances when we aren’t using them, use earbuds, plant more trees, and provide regular maintenance of vehicles and machines.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Next time you or a parent cooks, upload a photo of the pan getting warm and what thermal source it is connected to.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How would you describe the concept of thermal conductivity to a student younger than you? How would you describe it to an adult? Write two different explanations.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the various materials into whether they have high and low thermal conductivity.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: In the next few lessons, we will focus on this SDG in the effort to further understand how we can support this goal. Take this time to read through the website and summarize your initial reactions to the goal here.

content.text: Thermal conductivity refers to the transfer of heat, which is an important concept, not just in Physics class. The United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) #7, is Affordable and Clean Energy. Through the hyperlink, you will be brought to the United Nations’ website where they explain this goal in further detail.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of something that is affected by the level of thermal conductivity present.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe five ways in which thermal conductivity is present in your life.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following situations into whether they clearly show thermal conductivity or not.

options.name: Demonstrate thermal conductivity
options.title: Hot tea is poured into a mug, making the mug warm as well.

options.name: Demonstrate thermal conductivity
options.title: The stove heats up and cooks an egg on a pan.

options.name: Do not demonstrate thermal conductivity
options.title: A plant grows taller after receiving water.

options.name: Do not demonstrate thermal conductivity
options.title: A species of bird goes extinct due to habitat loss.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: With the information from the table in mind, what could your household do to decrease your energy usage? Create a detailed plan that addresses how you plan to change the consumption of energy from the appliance and how realistic implementing this change would be.

content.text: One way that we can support the goal of Affordable and Clean Energy is to be conscious of our current use of energy in our homes. See the table below to better understand how different appliances use energy.

lessons.title: 8. Why Do You Need an Electroscope?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Upload a photo of a diagram drawn by you of an electroscope.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe in as few words as possible what an electroscope is.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following into whether the electroscope could be useful or not.

options.name: Useful
options.title: Detect the presence of ionizing radiation

options.name: Useful
options.title: Calculate the form between two charges

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Present to your family and focus on implementing this plan across a week. Upload your presentation here!

content.text: Think back to the plan you made last lesson to reduce energy consumption. In order to enact your plan and make a real difference, we need to get your household on board! Create a presentation that details your plan, why this plan would be effective, why others should care about their energy consumption, and the positive impacts that could come from this change.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Upload a photo of three household objects that conduct electricity.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Explain what materials conduct electricity and which materials do not.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Do some research on companies that have made strides in this area, and find one that you think could use some of those practices to improve. Write an open letter to the corporation, company, or industry addressing your concerns, what they could do better, and overall convince them to make a change.

content.text: Understanding how individuals can contribute to the goal of Affordable and Clean energy is a huge step in the right direction. What would be even better is if industry and large corporations also took important steps, including the implementation and use of clean and renewable energy.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo of any household items that you know are made of minerals. Identify the mineral(s) present.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Explain what makes a material a mineral versus not a mineral. Give examples of minerals and substances you could rule out as minerals.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following substances into whether they are minerals or are not minerals.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Plastic is a material that has had a huge impact on wildlife around the world. You probably have heard about all of the problems it causes, but what actually is it? Conduct research and write a paragraph summarizing what plastic is and the largest negative impacts it has on the environment.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo of rocks native to your local park, beach, or general area. Rocks often contain two or more minerals.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe the process of mineral formation in one paragraph.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the following layers of the earth in order, starting with the outermost layer.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the following processes that lead to mineral formation into whether they apply to the formation of igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic rocks.

options.name: Igneous
options.title: Magma from volcanic eruptions gets to earth and cools, forming rock.

options.name: Sedimentary
options.title: Pieces of other rocks or biological remains accumulate to create rock.

options.name: Metamorphic
options.title: Rocks experience high temperatures of pressure to create new kinds of rocks.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Last lesson we focused on getting to the bottom of what plastic really is. With that information, spend an hour walking around outside and picking up plastic (or any garbage) and disposing of it properly. Take pictures to show your progress.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photo of an area outside that would be very seriously harmed if a combustible material was ignited there. Dry and wooded conditions can easily spread fires.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe what makes a material combustible and what makes a material fire-resistant.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the materials into combustible materials versus noncombustible materials.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: One big problem with plastic is that it takes a really long time to break down, increasing its harm to the environment. View the chart below to see how it compares to other materials. Can you think of something that is made of plastic that could instead be made out of one of these other materials that could break down easier? Explain your creative solution!

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Photograph an area nearby you would be likely to find ore minerals.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is the difference between ore minerals and regular minerals? Would you be able to identify the difference?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following into ore minerals or regular minerals.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: List three ways the country can take the profits from mined ore minerals to invest in the sustainable development of the country.

content.text: Kazakhstan holds vast mineral reserves which are largely undeveloped. The country possesses 30 % of the world's chrome ore reserves, 25 % of manganese ore, 10 % of iron ore, 5.5 % of copper, 10 % of lead and 13 % of zinc, according to official estimates.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Upload a photo of something made of a ferrous metal which may lay inside or around your home.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What does a metal need to contain to be considered ferrous?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the metal according to whether they are ferrous or non-ferrous.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Create a plan for these large mining companies to donate profits back to the city and country to reduce nationwide pollution output.

content.text: A metal with the descriptor “ferrous” means that it has iron in its composition. Mining of ferrous metals is popular but causes pollution in the process. Mining companies often have to pay a negative externality tax that may not directly be in the form of cash to compensate for their creation of pollutants.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw a diagram highlighting what an object needs to be considered a metal and upload a picture.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What would you need in order to identify whether something is a metal or not?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following substances as either metallic or non-metallic.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Once you identify this item, do some research to find an alternative already on the market that is more sustainable by not being a single use item. Summarize the product, how it would improve on the less sustainable product you currently use, and how you think it could improve.

content.text: Everything that we use is made out of substances that when disposed of, have some sort of impact on the environment. Identify an item in your life that you use one time and dispose of. For example, using a baby wipe to clean and then throwing it out. This makes the baby wipe single use.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Upload a photo of a non-metallic mineral or something made out of a non-metallic mineral which may lay inside or around your home.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What does a material need to contain to be considered non-metallic?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the following properties into whether they apply to metals or nonmetals.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: If the sustainable option is less affordable, what would you suggest to the company to make it more competitive? Are there any other reasons other than affordability that would keep a customer from choosing the environmentally friendly alternative?

content.text: Think back to the sustainable alternative you found in the last lesson. Is this product more or less affordable than the less sustainable option? Why do you think this is?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of something you couldn't live without. What minerals are necessary in the creation of it?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Is it possible for us to ever run out of mineral resources? If so, how would that impact the rest of the earth and human life?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Many minerals are very high in demand and many corporations are scrambling to figure out how they will meet that demand in the future. To better understand what is required of the items we own, match the item to the mineral that is required to make it.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Name and detail three ways that these mineral profits can be used to build infrastructure for the country to become more sustainable.

content.text: Gemstones in Kazakhstan including emeralds, sapphires, topazes and tourmalines, and high-quality quartz are popular exports of the country.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw a diagram of a renewable energy source that could avoid or improve the use of valuable natural resources. Upload a picture of the diagram.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Identify a material that can replace a valuable natural mineral and explain how it could replace it. You may have to do some research to answer this question!

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: A fun way to do this on your own is to create a piece of art out of household items that would otherwise be disposed of. Collect waste for a week and use it to create a work of art, it could be a sculpture, prototype of an invention, diagram, anything! Use this opportunity to get creative and demonstrate how waste can be recycled in a literal way to make something brand new! Upload a picture.

content.text: At this point, you must understand the value of the resources we already have on Earth. Many resources are limited, making recycling a very important activity for every citizen to participate in. We can create brand new things from those no longer needed.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Photograph any visible effects you notice in your environment that come as a result of mining.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe at least two pros and two cons that come as a result of mining.

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the impacts of mining into whether they are positive or negative.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Upload an image of the place you suggest this change to be made and create a plan of how you would achieve this.

content.text: Recycling is of course important, but there are many places including, homes, businesses, schools, that don’t make it easy for people to recycle. Look around your city and think critically to identify places that could provide an easy way for people to recycle and that don’t already.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Upload a photo of the minerals native to your environment.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What mining occurs near you? What corporations conduct it?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Sort the mining practices into whether they are sustainable or unsustainable operations.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Write a letter to the owner of the place that you identified in the previous lesson. Explain in your letter why you think that they should implement a way to recycle in this area, the positive impacts it could have, and your proposed plan. Try to convince them to actually follow through on your plan!

content.title: common:snapshot

content.title: common:memory
content.prompt: Match the continent to its image.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Find a globe or map. Highlight what shape the earth and why you think that shape exists. What do you notice about the variety of colors on the map and what do the colors signify? Try drawing earth and coloring it in, putting a circle around where you live.

content.title: common:snapshot

content.title: common:snapshot

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Describe how variance in elevation affects life.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Relief being the difference between the lowest and highest point of a given area represents the space between our planets and constellations and the earth’s core. Polluted air often stays trapped in space and is our bank of oxygen. List three creative ways to improve the quality of this air and draw an image of the city with these methods being added to the image.

content.title: common:snapshot

content.title: common:imageboom

content.prompt: Order these things in space according to how far away they are from you.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Look at the sky at night and detail what you notice. What colors and figures stand out and how does it look relative to earth? Can you see the stars? If not, what does pollution have to do with it?

content.title: common:snapshot

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Search up the solar system. Draw all of the planets and explain what direction they move in. What is their relation to the sun and how does the quality of air and pollution influence our relationship with the sun?

lessons.title: 7. How Does the Earth Revolve Around the Sun?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: When the earth revolves around the sun, how does that impact the weather? In times when the temperature is lower, how does your country create heat? Find the most unsustainable way to create heat and provide replacements for each that are more sustainable.

lessons.title: 8. How Do the Sun’s Rays Land on Earth?

Shine a light through the cloud and write what you observe about light and its interaction with the atmosphere.

Document how the presence of trash sitting on the surface level of the water can impact the bodies of life living in that ecosystem.

Draw how you view pollution collecting within the city and write the top three solutions to reducing this pollution.

content.text: Buoyant force acts against the basketball

Notice that there is an upward force causing the water level to rise and for the object to push back up against your force pushing it down. What do you observe and what is causing this upward force?

lessons.title: 5. How do Bodies Float in Water?

content.title: common:sorting

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: The use of solar panels is increasing in their presence and ability. Detail three implementation strategies of attaching solar panels to floating bodies and other remote objects.
